name: Laueana Butterwort
description: Pinguicula laueana is a small carnivorous plant native to Mexico, particularly in the state of Oaxaca. It belongs to the Lentibulariaceae family and features a compact rosette of sticky, bright green to red-tinged leaves (3-5 cm long) that secrete mucilage to trap and digest insects. The leaves curl inward when an insect is trapped, increasing contact area for digestion. The plant displays a rosette-forming growth habit and typically reaches 5-8 cm in height. It produces small, pink to purple flowers in spring and summer. These carnivorous plants secrete sticky mucilage that not only traps insects but also has antibacterial properties. In its native habitat, it grows in nutrient-poor, wet soils in high-altitude regions. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant offers unique intrigue with its rosette form and dewy, jewel-like appearance. It's popular among carnivorous plant enthusiasts for its compact size and attractive flowers.
careTips: Requires distilled or rain water only
